Package com.google.mu.util.stream

Class Walker<T>

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.google.mu.util.stream.Walker<T>
  • public class Walker<T>
extends java.lang.Object
    Implements generic graph and tree traversal algorithms (pre-order, post-order and breadth-first) as lazily evaluated streams, allowing infinite-size graphs.

    None of these streams are safe to run in parallel.

    Since:
    3.9

    • Method Detail

      • forTree

        public static <T> Walker<T> forTree​(java.util.function.Function<? super T,​? extends java.util.stream.Stream<? extends T>> getChildren)
        Returns a Traversal object assuming tree structure (no cycles), using getChildren to find children of any given tree node.

        The returned object is idempotent, stateless and immutable as long as getChildren is idempotent, stateless and immutable.

        WARNING: the returned Walker can generate infinite cycles if getChildren behaves like a graph with cycles (for example any undirected graph).

      • forGraph

        public static <T> Walker<T> forGraph​(java.util.function.Function<? super T,​? extends java.util.stream.Stream<? extends T>> findSuccessors)
        Returns a Traversal object assuming graph structure (with cycles), using findSuccessors to find successor nodes of any given graph node.

        The returned object remembers which nodes have been traversed, thus if you call for example preOrderFrom(T...) again, already visited nodes will be skipped. This is useful if you need to imperatively and dynamically decide which node to traverse. If you'd rather re-traverse everything, recreate the Traversal object again.

        Because the Traversal object keeps memory of traversal history, the memory usage is linear to the number of traversed nodes.

      • preOrderFrom

        @SafeVarargs
public final java.util.stream.Stream<T> preOrderFrom​(T... initials)
        Starts from initials and traverse depth first in pre-order by using findSuccessors function iteratively.

        The returned stream may be infinite if the graph has infinite depth or infinite breadth, or both. The stream can still be short-circuited to consume a limited number of nodes during traversal.

      • preOrderFrom

        public final java.util.stream.Stream<T> preOrderFrom​(java.util.stream.Stream<? extends T> initials)
        Starts from initials and traverse depth first in pre-order.

        The returned stream may be infinite if the graph has infinite depth or infinite breadth, or both. The stream can still be short-circuited to consume a limited number of nodes during traversal.

      • postOrderFrom

        @SafeVarargs
public final java.util.stream.Stream<T> postOrderFrom​(T... initials)
        Starts from initials and traverse depth first in post-order.

        The returned stream may be infinite if the graph has infinite breadth. The stream can still be short-circuited to consume a limited number of nodes during traversal.

        The stream may result in infinite loop when it traversing through a node with infinite depth.

      • postOrderFrom

        public final java.util.stream.Stream<T> postOrderFrom​(java.util.stream.Stream<? extends T> initials)
        Starts from initials and traverse depth first in post-order.

        The returned stream may be infinite if the graph has infinite breadth. The stream can still be short-circuited to consume a limited number of nodes during traversal.

        The stream may result in infinite loop when it traversing through a node with infinite depth.

      • breadthFirstFrom

        @SafeVarargs
public final java.util.stream.Stream<T> breadthFirstFrom​(T... initials)
        Starts from initials and traverse in breadth-first order.

        The returned stream may be infinite if the graph has infinite depth or infinite breadth, or both. The stream can still be short-circuited to consume a limited number of nodes during traversal.

      • breadthFirstFrom

        public final java.util.stream.Stream<T> breadthFirstFrom​(java.util.stream.Stream<? extends T> initials)
        Starts from initials and traverse in breadth-first order.

        The returned stream may be infinite if the graph has infinite depth or infinite breadth, or both. The stream can still be short-circuited to consume a limited number of nodes during traversal.
